rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 }
{\rtf1 welcome to Tec m51 95 we're continuing}
{\rtf1 in honoring for style section of the}
{\rtf1 course and specifically we'll talk about}
{\rtf1 editing for passive and active voice as}
{\rtf1 I've been trying to do I'm trying to}
{\rtf1 contextualize teaching editing passive}
{\rtf1 and active voice to teaching it in your}
{\rtf1 own classrooms of technical}
{\rtf1 communication so three things that I'll}
{\rtf1 point out and I'll also sort of pepper}
{\rtf1 in some other strategies as we go}
{\rtf1 through editing these editing for}
{\rtf1 passive active voice but three things}
{\rtf1 that I want to point out one you can use}
{\rtf1 humorous examples and I think this is}
{\rtf1 probably universal for teaching any kind}
{\rtf1 of writing but I like to use humorous}
{\rtf1 examples for teaching passive and active}
{\rtf1 so one example that I typically use is}
{\rtf1 if someone clogged the toilet would you}
{\rtf1 want to call that person out or not}
{\rtf1 right so if you did you might use active}
{\rtf1 voice John clogged the toilet versus}
{\rtf1 passive the toilet was clogged right so}
{\rtf1 the two have very different outcomes}
{\rtf1 depending on depending on whether or not}
{\rtf1 you choose passive or active as you're}
{\rtf1 writing it so you can use some humorous}
{\rtf1 examples that help students remember the}
{\rtf1 difference more easily secondly we can t}
{\rtf1 use passive and active to teach ideas}
{\rtf1 and concepts of audience context and}
{\rtf1 purpose because really the main idea of}
{\rtf1 passive and active voice are its two}
{\rtf1 ways to construct particular sentences}
{\rtf1 and one is not necessarily better than}
{\rtf1 the other and it's important to teach}
{\rtf1 students these ideas of one is better}
{\rtf1 suited for particular audiences or for}
{\rtf1 particular context of particular}
{\rtf1 purposes so this sort of rhetorical}
{\rtf1 triangle this idea of teaching these}
{\rtf1 rhetorical principles to students as}
{\rtf1 you're teaching them passive active}
{\rtf1 voice is a really good thing to do and}
{\rtf1 then thirdly you can connect teaching}
{\rtf1 passive and active voice to the larger}
{\rtf1 writing process so again if this idea of}
{\rtf1 writing is not a prescriptive set of}
{\rtf1 rules it's not a do this and you'll have}
{\rtf1 an effective piece of writing the same}
{\rtf1 is with passive and active voice it's}
{\rtf1 not a thing where there's a prescriptive}
{\rtf1 set of}
{\rtf1 rules that say only use active voice or}
{\rtf1 only use passive voice it's important to}
{\rtf1 to teach students that it's that writing}
{\rtf1 is contextually bound and so those are}
{\rtf1 three ways that you can sort of teach}
{\rtf1 passive and active voice in a technical}
{\rtf1 communication classroom some some}
{\rtf1 strategies for that okay so before we}
{\rtf1 can decide between active versus passive}
{\rtf1 voice when to use one or the other and}
{\rtf1 if we're teaching technical}
{\rtf1 communication we need to actually be}
{\rtf1 able to identify active versus passive}
{\rtf1 voice and so this comes from revising}
{\rtf1 professional writing and I think it's a}
{\rtf1 really good way to to identify both}
{\rtf1 active and passive voice so when we're}
{\rtf1 identifying active voice or passive}
{\rtf1 voice we're looking at sentences in two}
{\rtf1 different ways or through two different}
{\rtf1 lenses so the first is through a somatic}
{\rtf1 lens so we're we're looking at what are}
{\rtf1 the actual what are the actual}
{\rtf1 components of the sentence doing and so}
{\rtf1 we can look at them in three roles agent}
{\rtf1 action in patient so agent is the thing}
{\rtf1 that is doing the action and the patient}
{\rtf1 is the thing that is receiving the}
{\rtf1 action okay we can also look at}
{\rtf1 sentences syntactically when we've got}
{\rtf1 subjects which are the first noun phrase}
{\rtf1 in a sentence we've got a verb then}
{\rtf1 we've got direct objects whatever}
{\rtf1 follows the verb phrase and so we have}
{\rtf1 AI active voice when the agent is in the}
{\rtf1 subject position when the agent is in}
{\rtf1 the subject position so the first thing}
{\rtf1 we need to do when we're identifying}
{\rtf1 voice is identify the agent in the}
{\rtf1 patient what are the agents in the}
{\rtf1 patient in this sentence and so the}
{\rtf1 easiest way to do that is to just go}
{\rtf1 straight to the verb and to go okay the}
{\rtf1 verbs completed someone has to someone}
{\rtf1 or something has to complete something}
{\rtf1 find that okay the student that's the}
{\rtf1 thing that completed the thing and then}
{\rtf1 something has to receive the}
{\rtf1 action of the verb the project that's}
{\rtf1 the patient so when the agent is in}
{\rtf1 subject position when the agent is the}
{\rtf1 first noun phrase in a sentence you've}
{\rtf1 got active voice so in this case the}
{\rtf1 student which is our agent is in subject}
{\rtf1 position it's the first noun phrase so}
{\rtf1 this is an example of active voice the}
{\rtf1 opposite is true for passive voice}
{\rtf1 whatever the patient is in the subject}
{\rtf1 position you've got passive voice right}
{\rtf1 and so we know that our patient is the}
{\rtf1 project because our verb is completed}
{\rtf1 someone has to complete something the}
{\rtf1 project can't complete anything so we}
{\rtf1 know that the project is our patient so}
{\rtf1 the project is in subject position we}
{\rtf1 know that we have passive voice the}
{\rtf1 project was completed and then that by}
{\rtf1 phrase we can take it or leave it so}
{\rtf1 that's why that's in parentheses so you}
{\rtf1 could say the project was completed and}
{\rtf1 then you can just put a period after it}
{\rtf1 that's called an agentless passive}
{\rtf1 there's no there's no agent or we could}
{\rtf1 say the project was completed by the}
{\rtf1 student in which case we've added that}
{\rtf1 by phrase which is our the actual agent}
{\rtf1 of our sentence okay so that's}
{\rtf1 identifying active and passive voice}
{\rtf1 active is agent is in subject position}
{\rtf1 passive voice is patient is in subject}
{\rtf1 position other markers of passive voice}
{\rtf1 you need a verb form of to be followed}
{\rtf1 by the past participle and if you see an}
{\rtf1 optional by phrase that's also a good}
{\rtf1 clue that you've got passive voice let's}
{\rtf1 take a second in practice identifying}
{\rtf1 active and passive voice click anywhere}
{\rtf1 on the screen to launch the practice}
{\rtf1 exercise okay so now that we're able to}
{\rtf1 exercise okay so now that we're able to}
{\rtf1 identify active and passive voice let's}
{\rtf1 talk about how we how can we decide}
{\rtf1 whether or not to use active versus}
{\rtf1 passive there's really three things I}
{\rtf1 want to cover and the first is}
{\rtf1 determining the focus of the sentence}
{\rtf1 the second is using passive for}
{\rtf1 generalizable actions and results and}
{\rtf1 then the third is to be consistent for}
{\rtf1 cohesion we won't}
{\rtf1 really look at the third one very}
{\rtf1 closely so I'll just quickly say if}
{\rtf1 you're going to start a paragraph with}
{\rtf1 active voice you probably want to}
{\rtf1 complete the paragraph of active voice}
{\rtf1 and vice versa with passive so to}
{\rtf1 determine the focus of the sentence so a}
{\rtf1 basic rule of thumb is use active voice}
{\rtf1 to focus on the agent use passive voice}
{\rtf1 to focus on the patient so thinking}
{\rtf1 through again rhetorically and}
{\rtf1 contextually what do you want to}
{\rtf1 highlight in this sentence as an editor}
{\rtf1 and a writer so we can take a look at}
{\rtf1 these two examples the top is a passive}
{\rtf1 voice sentence affordable tuition rates}
{\rtf1 were implemented and have led to}
{\rtf1 positive student satisfaction}
{\rtf1 the second is an active voice sentence}
{\rtf1 the president of the university}
{\rtf1 interblock implemented affordable}
{\rtf1 tuition rates which has led to positive}
{\rtf1 student satisfaction okay so neither one}
{\rtf1 of these is correct but we have to think}
{\rtf1 about the context so if the context is}
{\rtf1 you know the president is writing a an}
{\rtf1 annual report and wants to show off all}
{\rtf1 of his or her accomplishments for the}
{\rtf1 year they definitely want to use active}
{\rtf1 voice we want to focus on the agent the}
{\rtf1 doer of the action if the contact is we}
{\rtf1 want to write a piece of marketing}
{\rtf1 material to the parents of potential}
{\rtf1 students of this particular University}
{\rtf1 that context is very different we want}
{\rtf1 to focus on the patient we want to focus}
{\rtf1 on affordable tuition so we use passive}
{\rtf1 voice and we foreground the patient}
{\rtf1 affordable tuition rates were}
{\rtf1 implemented and have led to positive}
{\rtf1 student satisfaction we actually don't}
{\rtf1 even mention the president at all in the}
{\rtf1 passive voice version of this sentence}
{\rtf1 and so one of the things that I want to}
{\rtf1 really point out is it matters what the}
{\rtf1 context is the context is very very}
{\rtf1 important in deciding between passive}
{\rtf1 and active or is also something you can}
{\rtf1 continue to teach your students also you}
{\rtf1 can use passive voice for generalizable}
{\rtf1 actions and results so really think}
{\rtf1 about methods and results sections}
{\rtf1 an EM rad report if you've never heard}
{\rtf1 of an MRAP report these are scientific}
{\rtf1 reports MRAP stands for introduction}
{\rtf1 methods results and discussion so}
{\rtf1 basically every scientific research}
{\rtf1 article is written in this genre or in}
{\rtf1 this structure so if we take a look at}
{\rtf1 the first example the active voice}
{\rtf1 example I asked participants to complete}
{\rtf1 the survey it's kind of sound silly}
{\rtf1 because no one cares about the person}
{\rtf1 doing the X the asking especially in a}
{\rtf1 scientific research article they care}
{\rtf1 about the process so they care about the}
{\rtf1 participant they don't care about the}
{\rtf1 researcher all that much and so a}
{\rtf1 passive voice reading might be better}
{\rtf1 participants were asked to complete the}
{\rtf1 survey a few teaching tips when you're}
{\rtf1 teaching about generalizable actions and}
{\rtf1 results and when you're teaching about}
{\rtf1 active versus passive voice one you can}
{\rtf1 use this as an opportunity to teach}
{\rtf1 about the mrad report structure right so}
{\rtf1 this thing exists everyone that writes}
{\rtf1 science reports uses this convention you}
{\rtf1 should probably know it right so to}
{\rtf1 teach students about that you can also}
{\rtf1 teach students about genre conventions}
{\rtf1 but so part of genre conventions aren't}
{\rtf1 just the heading that you use or the}
{\rtf1 order by which these sections of the}
{\rtf1 report go and it's also the way that you}
{\rtf1 construct sentences and then thirdly you}
{\rtf1 can teach students use this to teach}
{\rtf1 students that passive voice is not evil}
{\rtf1 right passive voice oftentimes people}
{\rtf1 teach prescriptively and I say never use}
{\rtf1 passive voice it always it takes more}
{\rtf1 words it's more ambiguous sometimes}
{\rtf1 there's reason to be ambiguous and this}
{\rtf1 is one reason is you want to focus on}
{\rtf1 the patient when you're talking about}
{\rtf1 generalizable actions or results so}
{\rtf1 those are just some ways that you can}
{\rtf1 bring in passive and active into your}
{\rtf1 classroom so that's passive an active}
{\rtf1 voice there will be a short exercise for}
{\rtf1 choosing between the two do those}
{\rtf1 exercises and then we'll be through with}
{\rtf1 this video}
